newsitem.title: INDONESIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - March 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - March 17.

text.p: The following are the leading stories in the Indonesian press on March 17. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

More than a dozen people were injured in a football riot after fans invaded the pitch during a national league match being played in Tangerang on the outskirts of Jakarta. Hundreds of police and troops were deployed to control the disturbance.

Political analysts say the government should allow foreign as well as local non-government organisations to monitor the May general elections after it announced representatives from foreign governments would be invited as observers.
Moslem leaders have called for gradual democratisation and warned the community against violent change.

The central bank, Bank Indonesia, will impose administrative sanctions for banks which violate the expansion of credit, while a number of bank executives have asked the bank to give them a tolerance of between one and five percent on the maximum expansion limits.

Baharuddin Lopa, secretary-general of the official National Commission on Human Rights, has asked supporters of ousted minority party leader Megawati Sukarnoputri to call off a "Long March" from Bali to Jakarta planned to start next month.
